Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of the Princeton Summer School is to provide the next generation of combustion researchers and practicing engineers with comprehensive knowledge in the areas of combustion chemistry, theory, experiment, computation, and application. For the past seven years, the summer school session has offered daily morning and afternoon lectures taught at an accelerated pace over five days. The program typically consists of the foundational courses of combustion chemistry and combustion theory, as well as enrichment courses on practical combustion systems and laser diagnostics. The feedback from past participants has been uniformly enthusiastic for the learning and networking experience. The proposed support for graduate students and post-doctoral researchers is to partially offset part of the costs for travel and lodging (on Princeton's campus) at the 2016 Princeton-CEFRC-CI Summer School on Combustion. The camp-like environment provides ample opportunities for students to interact intimately with established researchers as well as among themselves. Such a learning opportunity is usually not offered on a university campus and should help develop the next-generation leader in combustion research and industry for the nation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Objective

The Summer School program was conceived by recognizing that while combustion is an interdisciplinary subject, due to limitations at individual institutions the training received by most combustion researchers has not been sufficiently comprehensive to equip them to make breakthrough discoveries. The Summer School therefore aims to offer advanced graduate level courses to remedy this deficiency.

The 2018 session of this annual summer school was supported by a substantial grant from the Combustion Institute (CI), with additional grants from NSF, KAUST and Princeton University. The session was thus entitled as 2018 Princeton-Combustion Institute Summer School on Combustion to reflect this substantial support from the Combustion Institute.

 

Approach

The 2018 session was held from June 24 through June 29. There were 185 participants coming from 16 countries and 26 US states, representing 65 US and non-US universities, 7 U.S. government labs and corporations, and 4 non-US corporations. 164 of the participants were graduate students and 21 were professionals.

For the academic program, the foundational courses of Combustion Theory and Combustion Chemistry were offered again, as in previous years. This year, Combustion Theory and Applications in CFD was taught by Professor Heinz Pitsch from the RWTH Aachen University, Germany, and Combustion Chemistry was taught by Professor Michael J. Pilling of the University of Leeds, UK. Three enrichment courses were also offered: Quantitative Laser Diagnostics for Combustion Chemistry and Propulsion was taught by Prof. Ronald K. Hanson of Stanford University; Internal Combustion Engines was co-taught by Prof. Rolf. Reitz of the University of Wisconsin at Madison and Dr. Gautam Kalghatgi of Saudi Aramco, Saudi Arabia; and Advanced Topics in Propulsion was co-taught by Prof. Timothy C. Lieuwen of the Georgia Institute of Technology and Prof. Richard A. Yetter of the Pennsylvania State University.

Detailed lecture notes were prepared and distributed to the participants in advance of the session and all lectures were professionally taped and made freely available to the general public through the Princeton University web site.

Participants lived in an air-conditioned dormitory setting and had meals together in the student cafeteria, hence facilitating networking. Room and board expenses for all U.S. students were covered by the summer school.

 

Relevance to NSF

Many participants were involved in research projects supported by NSF. The enrichment of their knowledge in combustion will benefit the progress of these research projects. Furthermore, it is anticipated that many of the graduate students will become active researchers in combustion and propulsion in the future, some assuming leadership positions. This Summer School experience will undoubtedly prove useful as they carry out their responsibilities.

 

Accomplishments for Reporting Period

  • 185 participants coming from 16 countries and 26 US states, representing 64 US and non-US universities, 7 U.S. government labs and corporations, and 4 non-US corporations. 164 of the participants were graduate students and 21 were professionals.
  • Participants were highly satisfied with the experience, with many laudatory feedback comments.
  • All lectures were professional taped and are freely available to the general public through the Princeton University web-site and YouTube at https://www.youtube.com/user/PrincetonCEFRC/videos
  • Detailed lecture notes are freely available to the general public through Princeton University?s web-site at https://cefrc.princeton.edu/combustion-summer-school/archived-programs/2018-session/lecture-notes
